Summary: Introduction to Counting the Mitzvos.
Principle 1:That it is inappropriate to count rabbinic commandments in this category
Principle 2: That it is inappropriate to count anything that we learn from the thirteen hermeneutic principles through which the Torah is expounded or from a (formal technical) inclusion.
Principle 3: That it is inappropriate to count commandments that are not practiced for [all] generations.
Principle 4: That it is inappropriate to count commands that include the whole Torah.
Principle 5: That it is inappropriate to count the reason for a commandment as a commandment on its own.

Principle 6: That it is appropriate with a commandment that includes [both] a positive commandment and a negative commandment, to count the positive commandment in it with the positive commandments and the negative commandment in it with the negative commandments.
Principle 7: That it is inappropriate to count the details of the commandments.
Principle 8: That it is inappropriate to count the negation of a positive commandment with the negative commandments.
Principle 9: That it is inappropriate to count the [statements] of the negative commandments and the positive commandments, but rather the items prohibited by them or commanded by them.
Principle 10: That it is inappropriate to count preliminaries that are for one of various purposes.
Principle 11: That it is inappropriate to count each of the parts of a commandment on its own, when their combination is one commandment.
Principle 12: That it is inappropriate to count parts of work, that are required by a command, on their own.
Principle 13: That the count of commandments not be increased according to the number of days that one is obligated in that commandment.
Principle 14: That it is inappropriate to count the enactment of (fences) [punishments] among the positive commandments.
To know there is a G‑d
We are commanded to believe in G-d's unity.
To know that He is one
We are commanded to believe in His awe, may He be exalted, and to be afraid of Him.
We are commanded to serve G-d through prayer.

We are commanded to associate with the sages, to gather with them and to constantly be involved with them in all manner of work and interaction in eating and drinking and business, so that it comes to us to imitate their actions and believe the truth of their words.
We are commanded to swear by His name when it is necessary to ratify something or to deny it.
We are commanded to imitate Him, may He be exalted, according to our ability.
We are commanded to sanctify His name.
Not to test the prophet unduly
We are commanded to study Torah and to teach it.
We are commanded to put on the head tefillin.
We are commanded to put on the hand tefillin.
We are commanded to make tzitzit (fringes).
We are commanded to make a mezuzah.
We are commanded to assemble the people on the second day of Sukkos at the end of the sabbatical year, and to read some sections of Devarim so they can hear it.
We are commanded that any king from our nation that sits on the royal throne should write a Torah scroll for himself, and that it not be separated from him.
We are commanded that every man among us should write a Torah scroll for himself.
We are commanded to bless Him after eating.

We are commanded to build a choice house for Divine service, in which there will be sacrifices and an eternal burning of fire; and to which there will be journeying and pilgrimage on the festivals, and gatherings every year.
Not to bear a grudge
We are commanded to guard the Temple and to constantly walk around it, to honor it, to exalt it and to aggrandize it.
We are commanded to serve G-d.
We are commanded to serve G-d.
We are commanded regarding priestly service.
We are commanded that the priests bless Israel with the Priestly Blessing.
We are commanded to place the bread of display always in front of Him.
We are commanded regarding priestly service.
We are commanded to burn a fire on the altar every day continuously.
We are commanded regarding priestly service.
We are commanded to send away the impure from the camp.
We are commanded to honor the seed of Aharon, to adorn and glorify them, and that we should place them on a level of priority and precedence.
We are commanded to serve G-d.
We are commanded to serve G-d.

We are commanded that we have oil made according to the special recipe, ready to anoint the high priest when he is appointed as He said, "The priest who is exalted above his fellows, on whose head the anointing oil has been poured" (Vayikra 21:10).
We are commanded that the priests serve in watches, each watch serving one week.
We are commanded to serve G-d.
We are commanded regarding priestly service.
We are commanded to sacrifice two one-year old lambs in the Temple everyday, and these are called the daily offerings (temidim).
We are commanded that the high priest offer a regular grain offering every day in the morning and in the afternoon.
We are commanded to offer additional sacrifices on Shabbat (two one-year old lambs).
We are commanded to offer additional sacrifices on Rosh Chodesh (first day of month).
We are commanded to offer additional sacrifices on all seven days of Pesach.
We are commanded to offer additional sacrifices on Shavuos.
We are commanded to offer additional sacrifices on Rosh Hashana.

We are commanded to bring two breads of chametz to the Temple with the sacrifices that come with the bread on Shavuos which is fixed for the bringing of the sacrifice, as it appears in Vayikra and that the priests eat the two breads, after their waving, with the lambs of the peace offering.
We are commanded to offer additional sacrifices on Yom Kippur.
We are commanded to offer additional sacrifices on Sukkos.
Not to pass your children through the fire to Molech
We are commanded to offer additional sacrifices on Shmini Atzeret.
We are commanded to offer the daily burnt offering (Tamid) twice daily.
We are commanded to ascend to the Temple three times a year.
We are commanded to appear [at the Temple] on festivals.
We are commanded to rejoice in the the festivals.
We are commanded to slaughter the Pesach-offering on the fourteenth of Nissan in the afternoon.

We are commanded to eat the lamb of the Pesach-offering on the night of the fifteenth of Nissan according to the stipulations mentioned and that is that it is roasted, that it is eaten in one house and that is eaten with matzah and bitter herbs (maror).
We are commanded that whoever was prevented from slaughtering the first Pesach-offering, slaughter the second Pesach-offering.
We are commanded to eat from the meat of the second-Pesach offering on the night of the fifteenth of Iyar over matzah and bitter herbs.
We are commanded to blow with trumpets in the Temple during the bringing of the holiday offerings.
We are commanded that any animal sacrifice that we offer be eight days old or more and not less.
We are commanded that all of that which we offer Him be consummate for its type flawless from blemishes that appear in Scripture and those that they pronounced as such from tradition.
We are commanded to offer salt on every sacrifice.
We are commanded with the process of the burnt-offering sacrifice.
We are commanded with the process of the sin-offering sacrifice, according to the description that is mentioned whatever sin-offering it may be.
We are commanded with the process of the guilt-offering sacrifice according to the description that is mentioned with His saying, "And this is the law of the guilt-offering" (Vayikra 7:1).

We are commanded with the process of the peace-offering sacrifices according to the description that is mentioned with His saying, "And if his sacrifice is a sacrifice of peace-offerings" (Vayikra 3:1).
We are commanded with the process of the meal-offering sacrifices, according to the description that is mentioned for each and every type.
We are commanded that the court should offer a sacrifice if they erred in a directive.
We are commanded that anyone who erred in a sin and is an individual offer a sin-offering sacrifice.
We are commanded to offer a sacrifice when a doubt arises about one of the big sins for which we are liable excision when volitional, and a fixed sin-offering when inadvertent.
We are commanded that one who does certain sins must offer a guilt-offering sacrifice.
We are commanded regarding the Temple.
We are commanded to confess the transgressions and sins that we have done before G-d and to say them together with [our] repentance.
We are commanded that any man who is healed from a discharge offer a sacrifice.
We are commanded that any woman who is healed from a discharge offer a sacrifice and that is two turtledoves or two young pigeons.
We are commanded that any woman after childbirth offer a sacrifice and that is a one-year old lamb as a burnt-offering, and a young pigeon or a turtledove as a sin-offering.
We are commanded that someone with tzaraas offer a sacrifice when he is healed from it.
We are commanded to extract a tenth of the animals that are born to us each year, to offer their fat and blood and to eat the rest in Jerusalem.
We are commanded to consecrate firstborn animals meaning, to separate and designate them for what is appropriate for one to do with them.
We are commanded to redeem the firstborn man, that we should give the money to the priest.
We are commanded that we should redeem the [firstborn] donkey specifically with a sheep, and it should not be redeemed with anything else.
We are commanded to behead the [firstborn] donkey if we do not redeem it.
The king must have a separate Sefer Torah for himself
We are commanded to offer all of the sacrifices in the [Temple].
We are commanded to bring any sin-offering, burnt-offering, guilt-offering and peace-offerings, which we are obligated, to the [Temple].
We are commanded to redeem consecrated animals which have developed blemishes, such that it becomes mundane and permissible to slaughter and eat it.
We are commanded that the substitute [of a consecrated item] be consecrated.
We are commanded regarding the service of Levites in the Temple.
We are commanded regarding the Temple.
We are commanded that priests wash their hands and feet before Temple service.
We are commanded to light the menorah daily in the Temple.
We are commanded that a nazarite should grow his hair.
We are commanded to shave the nazarite's head and to bring his sacrifices at the culmination of his nazariteship.
We are commanded to fulfill everything that we we take upon ourselves in speech, whether in an oath, a vow, charity, a sacrifice or anything else besides them.
We are commanded to administer the nullification of vows meaning the precept that He instructed us about these laws.
We are commanded that when any person touches a carcass, he becomes impure.
We are commanded to [administer the laws of impurity] of eight creeping creatures.
We are commanded to administer [the laws of] impurity of foods and drinks.
We are commanded that a menstruant woman be impure.
We are commanded that a woman after childbirth be impure.
We are commanded that a metzora be impure.
We are commanded to administer the laws of the impurity of a garment that has tzaraas, such that it be impure.
We are commanded that a house that has tzaraas be impure.
We are commanded that a zav be impure.
We are commanded that semen be impure.
We are commanded that a zavah be impure.
We are commanded to administer [the laws of] the impurity of a corpse.

We are commanded and instructed us [to administer] the laws of purification water, about which they said that it renders impure in one way and purifies in another way as is explained in the analysis of this commandment.
We are commanded that we immerse in the mikveh waters, and that we then become pure from one of the various types of impurities with which we have become impure.
We are commanded that the purification from tzaraas be according to the process written in Scripture (Vayikra 14).
We are commanded to remove the ashes from the altar.
We are commanded that a metzora (a person with tsaarat) be known to all, such that people will separate from him.

We are commanded to process the red heifer, so that its ashes be ready for one who needs it for purification from the impurity of a corpse as He said, "and it shall be for the congregation of the Children of Israel" (Bamidbar 19:9).
We are commanded to administer the law of human appraisals.
We are commanded with the law of animal appraisals.
We are commanded about house appraisals.
We are commanded about field appraisals.

We are commanded that anyone who benefits from consecrated property add a fifth; likewise if he eats consecrated food meaning if [a non-priest] ate from the priestly tithe inadvertently, he pays for what he ate or the measure of what he benefitted, with the addition of a fifth.
We are commanded that the sapling of the fourth year be completely holy.
We are commanded to leave over the corner of the produce, the trees and that which is similar to them.
We are commanded to leave over the gleanings.
To marry a wife by the means prescribed in the Torah (kiddushin)
We are commanded to leave over that which is called ollalot (incomplete clusters) for the poor when we harvest the vineyard.
We are commanded to leave over for the poor, that which falls and breaks off from the grapes when we harvest them.
We are commanded to extract the first-fruits and bring them to the Temple.
We are commanded to extract the great (priestly) tithe (terumah gedolah).
We are commanded to extract the tithe from agricultural produce.
To do Yibum (marry childless brother's widow)
We are commanded regarding the garments of the High Priest.
We are commanded to extract the poor tithe every third year of the sabbatical [cycle], as well as the third year from every third year meaning the sixth year of the sabbatical [cycle].

We are commanded to declare in front of Him the fulfillment of the regulations of the tithes and the priestly tithes; and to be clear from them also in speech, the same way we are clear from holding them back in deed.

We are commanded to tell over His kindnesses that He benefited us and saved us and one begins with the topic of our father, Yaakov, and finishes with the toil of the Egyptians and their afflicting us to praise Him about all of this; and to request from Him to continue the blessing, at the time that one brings the first-fruits.
We are commanded to separate the loaf (challah)-tithe from our dough and to give it to the priest.
We are commanded to render ownerless all that grows from the ground during the sabbatical year and permit the growth of all of our lands to any person.
We are commanded to rest from any agricultural work on the seventh year.
We are commanded to sanctify the fiftieth year that is to say, to cease working during it.
We are commanded to blow the shofar on the tenth day of Tishrei of this year to announce the freedom of the slaves, and that every Jewish slave go out to freedom on the tenth day of Tishrei.
We are commanded to return all the lands to their owners in this year, and that they go out from their buyers without [payment].
We are commanded that there be [the possibility of] redeeming lands sold within the city wall only until the end of a year.
We are commanded to count the years and the sabbatical cycles until the Jubilee year, once the land has been conquered and we have subdued it.
We are commanded to release monies meaning all debts on the sabbatical year.
We are commanded to press the gentile and to force him to pay his debt, just as we have been commanded to pity the Jew and have been prohibited from pressing him.
We are commanded to give to the priest, the shoulder, the cheeks and the stomach from every sacrifice of pure animals that we slaughter.
We are commanded to give the first shearing to the priest.
We are commanded to administer the laws of dedications.
We are commanded to slaughter a beast, animal or bird and then to eat its meat; and that it only be permissible to eat their meat by slaughtering [it].
Not to marry a woman and her son's daughter
Not to marry a woman and her daughter's daughter
We are commanded to check for the signs of beasts and animals that can be slaughtered and that is that they chew the cud and have split hooves and it is then permissible to eat them.
We are commanded to check for the signs of birds, such that only some of them are permissible.
We are commanded to check for the signs of locusts as well.
We are commanded to check for the signs of [permissible] fish, which are written [in the Torah].
We are commanded to sanctify (proclaim) the months (in other versions, and to calculate the months) and years.
We are commanded to rest on Shabbos.
We are commanded to sanctify the Shabbos and to say things at its beginning and its culmination.
We are commanded to destroy chametz from our homes on the fourteenth day of Nissan.
We are commanded to tell about the Shemos from Egypt on the night of the fifteenth of Nissan at the beginning of the night according to the speaker's linguistic abilities.
We are commanded to eat matzah on the night of the fifteenth of Nissan whether there is a Pesach lamb or not.
We are commanded to rest on the first day of Pesach.
We are commanded to rest from work on the seventh [day] of Pesach.
We are commanded to count forty-nine days from the harvesting of the omer.
We are commanded to rest from work on the day of Atzeret (Shavuos).
We are commanded to rest from work on the First of Tishrei.
We are commanded to fast on the tenth day of Tishrei.
We are commanded to rest from work and [certain] actions on Yom Kippur.
We are commanded to rest from work on the first day of Sukkos.
We are commanded to rest from work on the eighth [day] of the holiday of Sukkos.
Not to castrate any male (including animals)
We are commanded to hold the lulav and to rejoice in front of the Lord seven days.
We are commanded to listen to the sound of the shofar on the first day of Tishrei.
We are commanded to give over a half shekel-coin each year.
We are commanded to listen to all of the prophets, to do all that he commands even against a commandment or a group of these commandments.
We are commanded to appoint a king upon us [that] he gather all of our nation and lead us.
We are commanded to listen to the Great Court and to do everything that they command us, to forbid and to permit.
We are commanded to follow the majority when there is a disagreement among the sages about any of the laws of the Torah.
We are commanded to appoint judges and officers to force the implementation of the Torah's commandments and to bring those inclining away from the true path back towards it.
We are commanded in this positive mitzvah.
We are commanded to testify in court about everything that we know.
We are commanded to investigate the testimony and to inquire [about] it well; and afterwards we judge the case and reach the truth.
We are commanded to render witnesses that testify falsely liable for the punishment that they thought to bring about with their testimony.
We are commanded to behead a calf according to its commandment when a corpse is found in the field and it is not known who killed him.

We are commanded to prepare six cities of refuge, such that they be ready for the accidental manslaughterer, that a path to them be fixed, that it be straightened and that nothing be left that would impede the fugitive from running [to them].
We are commanded to give cities to the Levites to dwell, since they do not have a portion and inheritance in the Land.
We are commanded to remove obstacles and dangers from all of our inhabitations.

We are commanded to destroy idolatry and all of its houses with all types of destruction, annihilation, breaking, burning, demolishing and cutting every type according to what will be most enhanced and quickest in the destruction.
We are commanded to kill all the people of a condemned city (ir hanidachat) and to burn the city with everything that is in it.
We are commanded to kill the seven nations that dwelled in the Land of Canaan and to destroy them, since they are the root of idolatry and its first base.
We are commanded to exclusively cut off the seed of Amalek males, females, adults and children from among the rest of the descendants of Esav.

We are commanded to remember what Amalek did to us in its coming forward to do us evil, to hate it at all times, to arouse the spirits with statements to fight with it and to make the nation alacritous to hate it such that the commandment not be forgotten with [the passing of] so much time.
We are commanded the law that He gave to us in a war with the other nations; and that is called an optional war.

We are commanded to appoint a priest that rebukes the people with the rebukes [needed for a] war and recalls whoever is not fit to fight whether from weakness [or because] his thoughts will be on a matter that will lead to a lack of courage in war and these are the three things explained by Scripture.

We are commanded that when our soldiers go out to war, we prepare them a path outside of the camps, such that the people go out and a man not do his needs everywhere and between the dwellings, like the [other] nations do.

We are commanded that there be a digging tool together with the other tools of war with each one of the men of war; so as to dig with it in the place that he defecates on that path that is designated for this.
We are commanded to return the stolen item itself, if it is still remaining as itself with the addition of a fifth if he swore [about it] or to give its value, if it was transformed.
We are commanded to give charity (tzedekah) and to strengthen the weak and to ease [their situation].
We are commanded to reward a Hebrew (Jewish) slave when he goes free, and not to have him leave [his owner's domain] empty-handed.
We are commanded to lend to the poor, to lighten his poverty from upon him and to ease [his condition].
We are commanded to demand interest from idolaters.

We are commanded to return the surety to its Jewish owner at the time that he has a need for it: If the surety is from that which he needs during the day such as tools of his craft or his activity he returns it to him during the day and holds it in surety at night; and if it is from that which he needs at night such as a pillow or a blanket he returns it to him at night and holds it in surety during the day.
We are commanded to give the wage of an employee on its day, and not to delay it to another day.
Not to eat diverse seeds planted in a vineyard
We are commanded to unload the load from upon an animal when it gets tired from its load upon the way.
We are commanded to raise up the load upon an animal or a person when he is alone, after someone besides us has put it down.
We are commanded to return a lost object to its owners.
We are commanded to rebuke a sinner, or one who wants to sin, and to prevent him from it with words of rebuke.
To cover the blood (of a slaughtered beast or fowl) with earth
We are commanded to love converts.
We are commanded to justify the leveler, the scales, the weights and the measures; and to maximize their exactness.
Not to swear falsely in G‑d's Name
Not to take G‑d's Name in vain
Not to deny possession of something entrusted to you
We are commanded to be fruitful and multiply, with the intention of preserving the species.
We are commanded to marry with kiddushin: To give something into the hand of the woman; through a contract; or through sexual intercourse.
To fulfill what was uttered and to do what was avowed
We are commanded to circumcise a boy.
We are commanded that a yavam (levirate husband) marry the wife of his brother when [the latter] dies without leaving offspring.
We are commanded that a yevamah (levirate wife) release her yavam if he does not marry her.
We are commanded that a rapist marry the woman he raped.
We are commanded the law of the one who puts out a bad name meaning to say, that He commanded us to give him lashes and that she be his wife.
We are commanded about the law of the seducer.
We are commanded about the law of the [captive woman of] beautiful form.
We are commanded - if one wants to divorce to divorce with a contract under all circumstances.
He must not eat grape skins
We are commanded to give lashes with a whip to those that transgress certain commandments.
We are commanded to remove an accidental killer from his city to a city of refuge.
We are commanded to kill, with a sword, those that transgress certain commandments.
We are commanded to strangle those that transgress certain commandments.
We are commanded to immolate those that transgress certain commandments.
We are commanded to stone those that transgress certain commandments.
We are commanded to hang some of those killed by the court.
We are commanded to bury those killed by the court on the day that they are killed.
We are commanded in this positive mitzvah.
We are commanded that the master who acquired a Hebrew (Jewish) maidservant marry her [he] or his son.
We are commanded to redeem the Hebrew maidservant.
We are commanded about the law of the Canaanite (gentile) slave.
We are commanded about the law of one who injures his fellow.
We are commanded to administer the laws of the ox [that causes damage].
We are commanded to administer the laws of the pit [that causes damage].

We are commanded to administer the laws of the thief that we fine him with the law of double-payment or four or five times, we kill him if he comes surreptitiously, we sell him and all of the regulations of the thief more generally, as explained in Scripture.
We are commanded about the law of grazing.
We are commanded about the law of fire damage.
We are commanded about the law of the unpaid guardian.

We are commanded about the law of the [paid guardian] and the renter since the law of the two of them is the same, as they explained and said (Shevuot 49b), "There are three laws for four [categories of] guardians.
We are commanded about the law of the borrower.
We are commanded about the law of buying and selling meaning the ways in which the sale between the seller and buyer is effectuated.
We are commanded about the law of claimant and defendant.
To leave the forgotten sheaves in the field for the poor
We are commanded in this positive mitzvah.
The positive commandments have been completed.
We are prohibited from believing in a god besides Him.
We are prohibited from making an idol to serve and there is no difference whether one made it with his hands or commanded that it be made.
We are prohibited from making an idol for those besides us, in order that they serve it and even if the one who commanded [us] to make it was a gentile.
We are prohibited from making images from wood, stones, metal and other [substances] and even though they are not made to worship.
We are prohibited from bowing to an idol.
Not to improperly preface one tithe to the next, but separate them in their proper order
We are prohibited from giving over some of our children to that object of worship that was famous at the time of the giving of the Torah, the name of which was Molekh.
We are prohibited from making an ov and that is that one burn a certain incense and do specific acts and it appears to him that he hears speech from below his underarm that answers what he asks it.
We are prohibited from doing the procedure of the yidaoni and this too is one of the types of idolatry.
We are prohibited from inclining towards idolatry and occupying ourselves with its narratives meaning to say, into this study of spirituality.
We are prohibited from making a pillar to which we attach ourselves and honor, even if it positioned to serve G-d upon it.
We are prohibited from making a stone that is designed to bowing upon, even if this was for [bowing to] G-d, may He be blessed.
We are prohibited from idolatry.
We are prohibited from swearing by an idol.

We are prohibited from preaching for an idol, and [for one] to call people to serve it and to make them enthused about it and even if the preacher does not do any of the actions [of idolatry] besides preaching about it.
We are prohibited from inciting.
Not to eat Second Tithe grains outside Jerusalem
Not to eat Second Tithe wine products outside Jerusalem
Not to eat Second Tithe oil outside Jerusalem
We are prohibited from an incited one from arguing the merit of the inciter.
We are prohibited from an incited one from being silent about something incriminating that he knows about the inciter that will bring about the punishment upon him.
We are prohibited from benefiting from the ornaments with which an idol is decorated.
The Kohanim must not eat the first fruits outside Jerusalem
We are prohibited from we not benefit from, or at all hold on to, wealth from a condemned city.
We are prohibited from attaching something from an idol to our wealth.
To give the shoulder, two cheeks, and stomach of slaughtered animals to a Kohen
To give the first shearing of sheep to a Kohen
We are prohibited from listening to one who prophesies in the name of an idol.
We are prohibited from we not be afraid of the false prophet, nor be negligent about killing him, because he prophesied in the name of G-d.
We are prohibited from following in the ways of the idolaters, and from behaving according to their practices and even with their clothing and with their gatherings in their assemblies.
We are prohibited from divination meaning to say, that one moves the faculty of imagination with a type of stimulus, like all of those with abilities to say what will happen before it does.
We are prohibited from doing actions chosen by astrology.

We are prohibited from soothsaying, such as the statement of the empty ones "I have already returned from the path, I will not finish all that I need"; "Today is Sunday, I will not benefit anything from having seen thing x.
We are prohibited from witchcraft entirely.
We are prohibited from being a charmer and that is saying things that they think will be effective for this.
We are prohibited from inquiring of someone with an ov.
We are prohibited from inquiring of a yidaoni.

We are prohibited from inquiring of the dead as is thought by those that are truly dead, even though they eat and feel and think that one who does such and dresses like this will have a dead person come to him during [his] sleep and tell him what he asks.
Not to refrain from lending immediately before the release of the loans for fear of monetary loss
We are prohibited from men adorning themselves with women's ornaments.
We are prohibited from inscribing colors such as blue, violet and others on our bodies, as is done by the idol worshippers.
We are prohibited from wearing a garment woven of wool and linen, like that which would be worn by the idolatrous priests at that time.
We are prohibited from removing the hair of the temples.

We are prohibited from shaving the beard and that is [specifically] five parts [of it]: The upper jaw on the right side; the lower jaw on the right side; the upper jaw on the left side; the lower jaw on the left side; and the [chin].
We are prohibited from making cuts in our flesh for the dead.
We are prohibited from dwelling in the Land of Egypt forever, so that we not learn from their practices and not follow their disgraceful ways.
We are prohibited from that we not wander after our hearts to the point that we believe doctrines that are the opposite of the doctrines that the Torah obligates us.
We are prohibited from making a covenant with the heretics meaning, with the seven nations (of Canaan) and to allow them to be secure.
We are prohibited from keeping someone from the seven nations alive so that people not isolate themselves with him and he incite them to idolatry.
We are prohibited from at all pitying idolaters and from lauding anything particular to them.
We are prohibited from settling idol worshippers in our land, so that we not learn their heresy, with His saying, "They shall not dwell in your land lest they cause [you] to sin, etc.
We are prohibited from marrying heretics.
We are prohibited from marrying Ammonites and Moabites exclusively the males even after they have entered the [Jewish] religion.
We are prohibited from distancing the descendants of Esav after they have entered the [Jewish] religion meaning to say, we are forbidden from avoiding marriage with them.
We are prohibited from not to distance the Egyptians and to abhor marriage to them, after they have entered the [Jewish] religion.
We are prohibited from ever making peace with Ammon and Moab.
We are prohibited from destroying trees in order to distress its people and sadden their hearts.
We are prohibited from being afraid of the enemies during the time of war, and that we not run away from them.
We are prohibited from forgetting that which the descendants of Amalek did to us that they were the first to hurt us.
We are prohibited from cursing the great G-d, may He be greatly exalted from that which the secterians say.
We are prohibited from violating an oath on an utterance.
We are prohibited from we not make a vain oath.
We are prohibited from desecrating [G-d's] name.

We are prohibited from not to test [His] assurances and threats of which His prophets have assured us, in the way of a doubt that we doubt them, once we have ascertained the truth of the prophet that is saying them.
We are prohibited from smashing and destroying houses of divine service; and from destroying books of prophecy, such that we not erase the glorious names [of G-d] and that which is similar to them.

We are prohibited from leaving one hung on a tree overnight; so that the 'blessing' of G-d not spread as a result of this, due to one's reflection when he sees it since we only hang a blasphemer and an idol worshipper.
No Levite must do another's work of either a Kohen or a Levite

We are prohibited from he prohibited the high priest from entering the temple at any time, due to the glory of the temple and its greatness, and [that] he should be afraid and scared of the divine presence.
We are prohibited from a priest with a blemish to enter the temple - meaning to say the altar, between the [entrance] hall and the altar and the sanctuary.
We are prohibited from slaughtering an animal and its offspring on the same day.
We are prohibited from a priest with a temporary blemish - such as scurvy or a scab or that which is similar to them - to serve [in the temple] so long as he has the blemish.
We are prohibited from taking the mother bird together with the young.
A Kohen must not enter the Temple intoxicated
We are prohibited from and scripture explains that one who transgresses this negative commandment is liable for death at the hands of the heavens.
We are prohibited from and in the ninth [chapter] of sanhedrin (sanhedrin 83b), they said, "from where [do we know that] an impure priest who served is [punished] with death.
We are prohibited from and one who transgresses this negative commandment is liable for death at the hands of the heavens.
We are prohibited from eating a limb torn from a living animal.

We are prohibited from any impure person from entering the camp of the levites - and that which is similar to it for [all] the generations: the temple mount, as they explained at the beginning of tractate kelim (kelim 1:8).
We are prohibited from building an altar of stones that have been touched by iron.
We are prohibited from ascending the altar by steps so that one not take a large step, but rather walk with the heel next to the toe.
We are prohibited from extinguishing the fire on top of the altar.
We are prohibited from offering any sacrifices on top of the golden altar in the sanctuary.
A Kohen must wash his hands and feet before service
We are prohibited from anointing [anyone] besides the high priests and kings with the anointing oil that Moshe made.
We are prohibited from making a vapor with the configuration of the [Temple] incense meaning that it be from those spices and proportionate to its measurements and have the intention to vaporize it.
We are prohibited from removing the poles of the ark from their rings.
We are prohibited from removing the breastplate from the ephod (a type of apron worn by the high priest), but rather that the breastplate be attached to it.
We are prohibited from tearing the edge of the robe of the high priest, but it should rather be woven to its border.
We are prohibited from we not sacrifice any of the sacrifices outside.
We are prohibited from slaughtering any of the sacrifices outside.
Not to sprinkle its blood
We are prohibited from sacrificing animals with blemishes.
We are prohibited from sprinkling the blood of animals with blemishes on top of the altar.
Not to sacrifice blemished animals even if offered by non-Jews
We are prohibited from offering animals with temporary blemishes.
We are prohibited from offering the sacrifices of gentiles when they are animals with blemishes; and we should not say, "Since he is a gentile, we will offer an animal with a blemish for his sake.
To offer only animals which are at least eight days old
We are prohibited from offering leaven or honey.
Not to burn honey or yeast on the altar
We are prohibited from offering a harlot's fee or the sale revenue for a dog.
We are prohibited from slaughtering an animal and its child on one day.
We are prohibited from placing olive oil in the meal-offering of a sinner.
We are prohibited from offering frankincense in the offering of a sinner.
We are prohibited from mixing the meal-offering of a sotah (suspected adulteress) [with oil].
We are prohibited from putting frankincense into the meal-offering of a sotah (suspected adulteress).
We are prohibited from substituting consecrated animals.
We are prohibited from changing consecrated animals from one sacrifice to another such as if they were peace-offerings, we may not go back to make them a sin-offering.
We are prohibited from redeeming a pure firstborn animal.
We are prohibited from selling the animal tithe in any fashion that it might be.
We are prohibited from selling a field which its owners have dedicated and even to the functionary who is appointed over consecrated property.
We are prohibited from redeeming unspecified dedications of land.
We are prohibited from severing the head of the fowl sin-offering at the time of nipping (melikah).
We are prohibited from doing work with consecrated animals.
We are prohibited from shearing the wool of consecrated animals.
We are prohibited from slaughtering the Pesach-offering over chametz (leavened grain products).
We are prohibited from leaving over the innards of the Pesach-sacrifice that were not sacrificed, until they became disqualified by laying overnight.
We are prohibited from leaving over any of the meat of the Pesach-sacrifice until the morrow, meaning the day of the [15th] (of Nissan).
We are prohibited from leaving over any of the meat of the festival-offering that he sacrifices on the 14th (of Nissan) to the third day, but rather to eat it within two days.
We are prohibited from leaving over any of the meat of the Second Pesach-offering until the morning.
We are prohibited from leaving over any of the meat of the thanksgiving-offering until the morning.
We are prohibited from breaking one of the bones of the Pesach-offering.
We are prohibited from breaking one of the bones of the Second Pesach-offering.
We are prohibited from removing any of the meat of the Pesach-offering outside of the place of the eating group.
We are prohibited from baking the remainders of meal-offerings with leaven.
We are prohibited from eating the Pesach-offering boiled or uncooked, but rather only roasted with fire.
We are prohibited from feeding the Pesach-offering to a resident alien (ger toshav).
We are prohibited from feeding the Pesach-offering to one uncircumsized.
We are prohibited from feeding the Pesach-offering to an Israelite who has defected.
We are prohibited from having anyone impure eat sacrificial foods.
We are prohibited from eating consecrated meat that has become impure.
We are prohibited from eating notar and that is what is left over from the meat of consecrated items after the time assigned for their eating.
We are prohibited from eating piggul.
We are prohibited from he prohibited all outsiders (non-priests) from eating priestly tithe.
We are prohibited from he prohibited a tenant of a priest, or his hired servant from eating the priestly tithe.
We are prohibited from he prohibited an uncircumcised one from eating the priestly tithe.
To offer the wave offering from the meal of the new wheat (on the 2nd day of Passover)
We are prohibited from he prohibited a desecrated woman (challalah) from eating the consecrated foods that had been permitted for her to eat - the priestly tithe, the breast and the thigh.
Biblical_Source: seven weeks from the day the new wheat offering was brought—Leviticus 23:15

Summary: We are prohibited from eating a meal-offering of a priest.
We are prohibited from he prohibited the priests from eating the meat of sin-offerings processed inside [the sanctuary].

We are prohibited from eating disqualified consecrated foods that are not permissible to eat and that is when we make a blemish intentionally, as is explained in Bekhorot (Bekhorot 35a); or that a sacrifice was disqualified after its slaughtering in one of the ways that spoil it, that prevent its eating.
We are prohibited from eating the second tithe from grain, outside of Jerusalem.
We are prohibited from consuming the second tithe from wine, outside of Jerusalem.
We are prohibited from consuming the second tithe from oil, outside of Jerusalem.
Not to eat sacrifices which have become unfit or blemished
We are prohibited from eating the sin-offering and the guilt-offering outside of the [Temple] courtyard.
We are prohibited from eating the meat of a burnt-offering.
We are prohibited from eating lighter consecrated food (kodashim kalim) before the sprinkling of their blood.
We are prohibited from an outsider not eat higher consecrated food (kodeshei hakodashim).
We are prohibited from he prohibited the priests from eating firstfruits outside [of jerusalem].
We are prohibited from eating second tithe when impure even in Jerusalem until it has been redeemed.
We are prohibited from eating second tithe when grieving even in Jerusalem until it has been redeemed.
We are prohibited from spending the [redemption] money of second tithe except for food and drink.
We are prohibited from eating tevel and that is [produce] from which the priestly tithe and the [other] tithes have not been separated.
We are prohibited from and the explanation by way of illustration is with wheat: when it is winnowed, it is tevel.
We are prohibited from delaying vows, voluntary offerings and other sacrifices which are obligatory for one.
We are prohibited from going up on pilgrimage without there being a sacrifice with us, such that we sacrifice it there.
We are prohibited from violating that which we have obligated ourselves with speech, even it is without an oath.
We are prohibited from a priest from taking (marrying) a zonah (a woman who had sexual relations with someone forbidden for any israelite to marry).
We are prohibited from a priest - that he not take (marry) a desecrated woman.
We are prohibited from a priest - that he not take (marry) a divorcee.
We are prohibited from eating consecrated meat that became impure.
We are prohibited from a high priest - that he not have sexual relations with a widow, even without marriage.
We are prohibited from eating outside the designated area (chutz limkomo).
We are prohibited from an impure priest eating consecrated food.
We are prohibited from a non-priest eating consecrated food.
We are prohibited from an ordinary priest from becoming impure for the dead, other then for his relatives that are enumerated in scripture.
We are prohibited from a high priest from entering under a roof together with a dead body, even for his relatives.
We are prohibited from a high priest from becoming impure from any dead body in any form of impurity - whether by touching or by carrying.
We are prohibited from the entire tribe of levi from taking a portion in the land [of israel].
We are prohibited from the tribe of Levi taking a portion in the booty when conquering the Land of Israel.
Not to leave the meat of the holiday offering of the 14th until the 16th
To be seen at the Temple on Passover, Shavuot, and Sukkot
We are prohibited from eating impure fish.
We are prohibited from eating impure birds.
We are prohibited from eating winged swarming things.
We are prohibited from eating things that swarm upon the earth, such as worms, beatles and that which is similar to them.
We are prohibited from eating things that swarm which come to exist from rot, even though they are not a specific type and do not come into existence from a male and a female.
We are prohibited from eating worms that are born in fruit and seeds from the time they go out and exit to the surface of those seeds or those fruits.
We are prohibited from eating any swarming thing that it might be without specification whether a swarming thing of the water or a swarming thing of the earth.
We are prohibited from eating a dead [animal].
We are prohibited from eating a torn [animal].
We are prohibited from eating a limb from a living animal.
We are prohibited from he prohibited [us] from eating the sciatic nerve.
We are prohibited from eating blood.
Bring an asham vadai offering [for certain sins] when guilt is ascertained
We are prohibited from cooking meat with milk.
We are prohibited from he prohibited [us] from eating meat with milk.
We are prohibited from eating meat from an ox that is to be stoned.
We are prohibited from eating bread made from the new grain before the completion of the sixteenth day of Nissan.
We are prohibited from eating parched grain made from the new grain before the end of the sixteenth day of Nissan.
We are prohibited from eating tender grain from the new [produce] before the end of the sixteenth day of Nissan.
Biblical_Source: see According to the Torah is Leprosy a hygienic problem or is it something spiritual and miraculous?) must bring an offering after going to the Mikvah—Leviticus 14:10

Summary: We are prohibited from eating orlah (fruit of trees during their first three years).
We are prohibited from eating forbidden mixtures specifically of the vineyard.
We are prohibited from drinking wine of (an idolatrous) libation.
We are prohibited from being gluttonous and drunk with food and drink in the days of youth and under the conditions of the law of the stubborn and rebellious [son].
We are prohibited from eating on the fast of Yom Kippur.
We are prohibited from eating chametz (leavened grain products) on Pesach.

We are prohibited from eating things that have an admixture of chametz (leavened grain products) [on Pesach] even though they are not bread such as (brine,) cereal and ale and that which is similar to them.
We are prohibited from eating chametz after midday of the fourteenth day of Nissan.
We are prohibited from chametz not be seen within all of our boundaries for seven days (starting on the 15th of Nissan).
We are prohibited from chametz not be found in our possession, even if we do not see it and even if it was deposited [elsewhere].
We are prohibited from the nazirite from drinking wine or [other drinks] the mixture of which [includes] grapes.
We are prohibited from he prohibited the nazirite from eating grapes; and if he ate a kazayit of grapes, he is lashed.
We are prohibited from he prohibited the nazirite from eating raisins.
We are prohibited from he prohibited the nazirite from eating grape seeds.
We are prohibited from he prohibited the nazirite from eating grape skins.
We are prohibited from the nazirite from becoming impure with a corpse.
We are prohibited from the nazirite from entering into the tent of a corpse.
We are prohibited from the nazirite from shaving.
We are prohibited from not to harvest all of what is planted.
We are prohibited from not to glean the sheaves that fall in the field at the time of the harvest.
We are prohibited from harvesting the ollalot (incomplete clusters) of the vineyard at the time of the harvest.
We are prohibited from not to gather the single grapes that fall in the vineyard at the time of the harvest.
We are prohibited from taking the forgotten sheaves.
We are prohibited from planting forbidden mixtures.
We are prohibited from planting grain as well as other vegetables in a vineyard.
We are prohibited from breeding forbidden mixtures of animals.
We are prohibited from doing work with a forbidden mixture of animals together.

We are prohibited from preventing an animal from eating from the thing upon which it is doing its work such that if it is threshing a threshing field or carrying straw on its back from one place to another, he may not prevent it from eating from it.
We are prohibited from working the land in the seventh year.
We are prohibited from doing work on trees in the seventh year.
We are prohibited from but according to the torah, we are allowed to eat what was planted on the sixth year - and that is called the aftergrowth - in the seventh year.
We are prohibited from picking the fruit which grew on the trees in the seventh year in the [same] way that we gather their fruits every year.
We are prohibited from working the land in the jubilee year.
We are prohibited from harvesting the aftergrowth in the Jubilee year.
We are prohibited from harvesting fruit of the trees in the jubilee year in the way that we collect [them] in other years.
We are prohibited from not to sell our land in the land of israel [as a] permanent sale.
We are prohibited from changing the open places of the Levites.
We are prohibited from abandoning and ignoring the Levites, regarding the giving of their due and gladdening them on the festival.
We are prohibited from not to claim debts on the sabbatical year, but rather to release them all.
We are prohibited from the refraining from lending to some of us because of the sabbatical year, so that [such a] debt not be released.
We are prohibited from refraining to give charity and comfort to our poor brothers, about whose poverty we are aware and whom we have the ability to support.
We are prohibited from the sending away of a hebrew (jewish) slave empty-handed when he goes out to freedom at the end of six years.
Not to murder
We are prohibited from and that is his, may he be exalted, saying, "your money you shall not give him on interest, and on increase you shall not give your food" (Vayikra 25:37).
We are prohibited from the borrower - that he should not borrow with interest.

We are prohibited from being involved with a loan with interest between a borrow and a lender - not to be a guarantor for one of them, not to be a witness for them and not to write a contract about what they agreed upon about the interest.
We are prohibited from not to oppress the employee and not to delay his wage with us.
Save someone being pursued even by taking the life of the pursuer
We are prohibited from keeping the collateral item from its owners during the time that he needs it.
We are prohibited from taking collateral from a widow - whether poor or rich - as it is stated (Devarim 24:17), "you shall not take a widow’s garment in pawn.

We are prohibited from taking in pawn, vessels with which people prepare their food, such as tools for grinding, kneading and cooking and tools for the slaughter of animals and other ones besides this that are grouped by the name, 'something with which food of sustenance (okhel nefesh) is made' as it is stated, "for it is a soul that he takes in pledge" (Devarim 24:6).
We are prohibited from - to not steal (kidnap) an israelite person.
We are prohibited from we not steal money.
We are prohibited from we not steal that to we which we do not have entitlement, by force and duress.
We are prohibited from we not steal the boundary of the land.
Not to put a stumbling block before a blind man (nor give harmful advice)
We are prohibited from we not deny obligations that we are indebted and deposits held by us.
We are prohibited from swearing [falsely] about the denial of money that is incumbent upon us [to pay].
We are prohibited from some of us from wronging others of us in trade and in buying and selling.
Buy and sell according to Torah law
We are prohibited from wronging the convert with words.
We are prohibited from wronging the convert and causing him damage in buying and selling.
We are prohibited from returning, a slave who ran away from outside of the Land to the Land of Israel, to his master.
We are prohibited from wronging a slave that runs away to us.
Purchase a Hebrew slave in accordance with the prescribed laws
Not to sell him as a slave is sold
Not to work him oppressively
Not to allow a non-Jew to work him oppressively
Not to have him do menial slave labor
We are prohibited from we not sell a Hebrew (Jewish) maidservant to someone besides ourselves.
We are prohibited from afflicting a hebrew (jewish) maidservant if one acquires her and marries her.
We are prohibited from we not sell a [captive] woman of beautiful form (yefat toar), after one had sexual intercourse with her once, after the capture of the city.
We are prohibited from exploiting a captive woman (yefat toar) after one has sexual intercourse with her.
The master must not sell his maidservant
We are prohibited from putting our thoughts to coveting that which is our brothers' (fellow Jews), and to desire it.
Not to extradite a slave who fled to (Biblical) Israel
Not to wrong a slave who has come to Israel for refuge
We are prohibited from ignoring a lost object.
We are prohibited from forsaking someone forlorn with a load stuck on the road.
Not to delay payment of wages past the agreed time
The hired worker may eat from the unharvested crops where he works
We are prohibited from doing inequity in judgement.
We are prohibited from and the prohibition about this content has already been repeated.

We are prohibited from and even if [the disputant] is great, honored and of stature, he should not show him favor in the case when he comes in front of him with his [fellow] disputant; and he should not inquire about his affairs and doings.
We are prohibited from the judge from being afraid of a man who is destructive, injurious and speaks haughtily; such that [the judge] should not incline the verdict towards him.
The courts must carry out the laws of an unpaid guard
Lend to the poor and destitute
We are prohibited from the judge - that he not have mercy upon someone who killed his fellow, or destroyed one of his limbs.
We are prohibited from the judge from slanting the judgement of converts and orphans.
We are prohibited from the judge - not to listen to one of the disputants when it is not in front of his [adversary].

We are prohibited from and the explanation of this is that when there is a disagreement between the judges about a sinner; and some say he is liable for the death penalty and others of them say he is exempt, and the ones who incriminate him count one more man than the ones acquitting - it is surely not permissible to kill that sinner.

We are prohibited from this means, do not seek to incline in a dispute - and that is that you incline with the majority or with the great [scholars], and that you remain silent about what your opinion is in this case.

We are prohibited from he prohibited the great court and the head of the yeshiva - not to appoint as a judge, a man who is not learned in the discipline of torah, on account of other virtues that he has, to appoint him because of them.
We are prohibited from and this has been repeated with a different language; and that is his saying, "vain testimony" (Devarim 5:17).
We are prohibited from the judge - that he not accept testimony of a sinner and not do anything based on his testimony.
Not to borrow with interest
We are prohibited from the judge to declare punishments, or to make one liable for money, with the testimony of one witness - even if he was most fit.
We are prohibited from the judge - not to kill someone clean and innocent.
The courts must carry out the laws of the plaintiff, admitter, or denier
We are prohibited from the witness from speaking about the case about which he testified.
We are prohibited from killing those liable for the death penalty when we see that they have already done a sin for which one is liable for death before their coming to the court.
We are prohibited from we not have compassion upon a pursuer.
We are prohibited from punishing someone forced, for the sin that he did - since he was forced into the act.
We are prohibited from the taking of ransom from an unintentional killer, so as to exempt him from exile.
We are prohibited from and that is his saying, "and you shall not take ransom for the soul of a murderer who is liable for death" (Bamidbar 35:31).

We are prohibited from being negligent about saving the life of someone when we see him in mortal danger, or [in a case of] loss, and we have the ability to save him such as if he was drowning in the river and we know how to swim and are able to save him; or if a robber is trying to kill him and we are able to foil his plan or repel his injury.
We are prohibited from leaving obstacles and stumbling blocks in our land and in our homes, so that people not die from them.
We are prohibited from some of us from making others stumble.
We are prohibited from hinting as if one will strike, even if he does not strike.
We are prohibited from being a talebearer.
We are prohibited from that some of us hate others of us.
We are prohibited from some of us not embarrass others of us; and that is what is called, whitening the face of one's fellow.
We are prohibited from some of us not take revenge upon some of us.
We are prohibited from we not bear a grudge, even if we do not pay him back.
We are prohibited from we not take the nest at the time of the snare the mother and the young.
We are prohibited from shaving off the scab [of tsaraat].
The court must not punish anybody who was forced to do a crime
A judge must not pity the murderer or assaulter at the trial
We are prohibited from keeping a sorcerer alive.
We are prohibited from a groom from leaving his home in order to be involved with one of the burdens for an entire year - not to go out to war, and not for anything besides it.
We are prohibited from dissenting against those who are the masters of the tradition and against their derivations from the commandments through the [methods] of Torah.
We are prohibited from adding to the Torah, both to what is written and to what is received.
A judge must not pervert a case involving a convert or orphan
We are prohibited from cursing a judge.
We are prohibited from cursing a nassi (elevated one).
We are prohibited from cursing any Israelite person.
Judges must not accept testimony unless both parties are present
Not to curse judges
Not to curse the head of state or leader of the Sanhedrin
We are prohibited from not walking outside of the city's perimeter on Shabbos.
We are prohibited from enacting the punishments against the sinners and enforcing the law against them on the Shabbos day.
We are prohibited from doing work on the the first day of pesach.
We are prohibited from doing work on the the seventh day of pesach.
We are prohibited from doing work on the day of atzeret (Shavuos).
We are prohibited from doing work on the day of Rosh Hashana.
We are prohibited from doing work on the first day of the holiday (Sukkos).

We are prohibited from and know that anyone who does work - whatever it may be - on one of these six days is lashed; unless it is from what is required for [the preparation of] food of sustenance (okhel nefesh).
We are prohibited from doing work on yom kippur.
We are prohibited from sexual intercourse with the mother.
We are prohibited from sexual intercourse with the father's wife.
We are prohibited from sexual intercourse with the sister.
We are prohibited from sexual intercourse with the daughter of his father's wife, when she is is sister.
We are prohibited from sexual intercourse with the daughter of the son.
We are prohibited from sexual intercourse with the daughter of the daughter.
We are prohibited from sexual intercourse with the daughter herself.
Fear your father and mother
We are prohibited from sexual intercourse with a woman and her son's daughter.
We are prohibited from sexual intercourse with a woman and her daughter's daughter.
We are prohibited from sexual intercourse with a sister of the father.
We are prohibited from sexual intercourse with a sister of the mother.
We are prohibited from sexual intercourse with the wife of the father's brother.
We are prohibited from sexual intercourse with the wife of the son.
We are prohibited from sexual intercourse with the wife of the brother.
We are prohibited from sexual intercourse with the sister of his wife during the lifetime of his wife.
We are prohibited from sexual intercourse with a menstruant during the period of her impurity meaning to say, all of the seven days.
We are prohibited from sexual intercourse with a married woman.
We are prohibited from sexual relations with animals their males and their females.
We are prohibited from having women engage in sexual relations with animals.
We are prohibited from sexual intercourse with a male.
We are prohibited from sexual intercourse with the father.
We are prohibited from idolatry.
We are prohibited from approaching one of these forbidden sexual relations - even without intercourse - such as [with] hugging and kissing, and similar such licentious acts.
We are prohibited from a mamzer (one born from certain forbidden unions - see the end of the previous commandment) not have sexual intercourse with an israelite.
We are prohibited from and the prohibition of this content was already repeated with a different language; and that is his saying, "do not profane your daughter to make her a harlot" (Vayikra 19:29).
We are prohibited from a man from bringing back his divorcee after she married someone else.
Prepare latrines outside the army camps
Prepare a shovel for each soldier to dig with
Appoint a priest to speak with the soldiers during the war
He who has taken a wife, built a new home, or planted a vineyard is given a year to rejoice with his possessions
We are prohibited from the destruction of male sexual organs of any animal species that it may be.
Not to panic and retreat during battle
We are prohibited from the king from having many horses.
We are prohibited from the king from having many wives.
We are prohibited from the king from having much money specifically for himself.
